Example

Given the matrix \[A=\left[\begin{array}{rr}2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right]\] find its determinant. What does this tell you about \(A^{-1}\)?

Solution

\[|A|=2\times (-2)-1\times 3=-7.\] Since \(|A|\neq 0\) then \(A^{-1}\) exists. Therefore, we can now find \(A^{-1}\):

\[A^{-1}=\dfrac{1}{(-7)}\left[\begin{array}{rr}-2&-3\\ -1&2\end{array}\right]=\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{array}{rr}2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right]\]
